questions.question: Which of the following statements about the anatomy of the gallbladder is false?

options.A: Valves of Heister are present around the neck of the gallbladder
options.B: Gall bladder has a very thick submucosal layer
options.C: Hartmann's pouch may hinder safe dissection of the cystic pedicle
options.D: Phrygian cap anomaly is not an indication for cholecystectomy

questions.question: While assisting a laparoscopic cholecystectomy for gallstones, the surgeon asks you to identifythe Calot's triangle. Which of the following structures does not form the boundaries of thistriangle?

options.D: The inferior surface of the liver

questions.explanation: GallbladderOMARROWSpiral valve ofheisterCystic ductCommon hepaticduct-Bile duct744The inferior surface of the liver forms the boundary of the hepatobiliary triangle, not Calot'striangle.Calot's triangle is an important surgical landmark as the cystic artery usually can be found withinits boundaries. The cystic artery should be identified while performing a cholecystectomy to avoiddamage to the extrahepatic biliary system.Occasionally, there can be a tortuous course of the right hepatic artery in some patients. This iscalled Moynihan's hump or caterpillar hump. It is an important anomaly that should berecognized in order to prevent intraoperative vascular and biliary injuries.Moynihan's HumpCystic arteryMoynihan's Hump(Tortuous righthepatic artery)OMARROWLeft hepaticarteryProper hepaticarteryCommonhepatic ductCystic ductCommonbile ductNote: The cystic artery is one of the contents as well as forms the superior boundary of the Calot'striangle (originally described in 1891 by Jean-François Calot)

questions.question: Which type of gallstones is most likely to be seen in the Asian population?
questions.explanation: The most common type of gallstone to be seen in the asian population is pigment stone (80%).The most common type of gallstone worldwide is mixed stone.Three main types of gallstones include:• Cholesterol stones - They consist of cholesterol monohydrate crystals. Pure cholesterol stonesare uncommon and account for <10% of all cases.••• Pigment stones (brown or black) contain <30% cholesterol:⚫ Black stones - Made up of insoluble bilirubin pigment polymer mixed with calcium phosphateand calcium bicarbonate. They are associated with hemolysis, usually seen in hereditaryspherocytosis or sickle cell disease.• Brown stones - Contain calcium bilirubinate, calcium palmitate, and calcium stearate, as well ascholesterol. They are also associated with the presence of foreign bodies within the bile ducts,such as endoprostheses (stents), or parasites, such as Clonorchis sinensis and Ascarislumbricoides.745• Mixed stones.The image below shows a resected specimen of the gallbladder with pigment stones.Struvite stone (triple phosphate stone) is a type of renal calculi. It is made of magnesium,ammonium, and phosphate.

questions.question: A 28-year-old obese woman underwent laparoscopic cholecystectomy and the specimen ofgallstones removed is given below. Which of the following is least likely to be a risk factor forthe formation of this type of gallstone in her?732
questions.explanation: The above image shows cholesterol gallstones. Hereditary spherocytosis is not a risk factor for theformation of cholesterol gallstones. Hereditary spherocytosis leads to the production of blackpigment stones.Obesity, high-caloric diets, prolonged fasting, certain medications (e.g., oral contraceptives), andresection of the terminal ileum result in increased secretion of cholesterol and supersaturation ofbile. This enhances the lithogenicity of bile.

questions.question: A 45-year-old woman was brought to the casualty with complaints of abdominal pain andvomiting. CT scan of the abdomen revealed the following finding. What is the most probablediagnosis?
questions.explanation: The CT image shows the Mercedes-Benz sign. It is a characteristic sign seen in gallstones.In gallstone, rarely, the center of the stone may contain radiolucent gas in a triradiate or biradiatefissure. This gives rise to characteristic dark shapes on a radiograph called the Mercedes-Benzsign (triradiate sign) or seagull sign (biradiate sign).746

questions.question: What percentage of gallstones are radio-opaque?
questions.explanation: Only 10% of gallstones are radiopaque.Approximately 90% of renal stones, 10% of gall stones, and 5% of appendicoliths contain enoughcalcium to appear radiopaque on plain films.Gallbladder diseases are regularly diagnosed by ultrasound because of the superficial location ofthe gallbladder and the absence of overlying bowel gas. Ultrasound has a high specificity andsensitivity for cholelithiasis. It is considered as the first test of choice for delineation of any biliarypathology. Stones appear acoustically dense and also produce an acoustic shadow. They also movewith a change in posture. However, CT provides superior anatomic information and therefore isindicated when more anatomic delineation is required.MI: 1,3747

questions.question: While performing the HIDA scan in a patient with gallstones, the gallbladder was notvisualized. What could be the possible diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Non-visualization of the gallbladder in HIDA (hepatobiliary iminodiacetic acid) scan is suggestiveof acute cholecystitis.Acute cholecystitis is the inflammation of the gallbladder that develops over hours, usuallybecause a gallstone obstructs the cystic duct. In the majority of cases, the process is limited by thestone slipping back into the body of the gallbladder. Clinical features include:• Pain in the right hypochondrium with referred pain to the back• Fever• Nausea, vomiting, dyspepsia•Jaundice• Positive Murphy's sign.• Positive Boas' signMurphy's sign: After asking the patient to exhale, the examiner places his hand below the costalmargin on the right side at the mid-clavicular line of the patient. The patient is then instructed totake a deep inspiration. If the patient stops breathing and winces with a 'catch' of breath,Murphy's sign is said to be positive.Boas' sign: It is the presence of an area of hyperaesthesia at the site of radiation of the pain to theback, typically, below the scapula.USG and CT scans are helpful in establishing a diagnosis. The gold standard investigation of acutecholecystitis is the HIDA scan. The radioisotope used is Technetium-99m (99mTc)-labeledderivative of iminodiacetic acid.The following image depicts the radioisotope scan in which the gallbladder is not visualized evenafter 4 hours.HIDA SCANDATE: 07-APR-2008NM 244 20085 MIN15 MIN30 MIN1 HR1.5 HRS2 HRS3 HRS4 HRS748Unlike bilirubin, iminodiacetic acid (IDA) compounds do not undergo conjugation in thehepatocytes. They are rapidly excreted into the bile. This enables excellent visualization of the bileducts and gallbladder within 30-60 minutes of injection.Since cystic duct obstruction initiates acute cholecystitis, there is non-visualization of thegallbladder 3-4 hours after the intravenous injection of 99m Tc-IDA. This is characteristic ofacute cholecystitis. Thus visualization of the GB establishes cystic duct patency and rules out acutecholecystitis.

questions.question: A 25-year-old patient was admitted with right hypochondriac pain and vomiting. USGdemonstrates a stone within the bile duct. All of the following clinical features can be seen inthis patient except:
questions.explanation: The presence of a stone within the bile duct is called choledocholithiasis. Murphy's sign is notseen in choledocholithiasis. It is seen in acute cholecystitis.Clinical features of choledocholithiasis:•• Right upper quadrant or epigastric pain, which may radiate to the back•Biliary colic• Vomiting•• Dyspepsia• Flatulence• Food intolerance particularly to fatty foods• Altered bowel habits• Jaundice.Other Murphy's in surgery:Murphy's punch sign: This test is performed by the examiner using the fist to make jabbingthrusts over the costovertebral angle. The test is positive in infection, inflammation, orobstruction of the kidney.The angle shown in the image is the costovertebral angle formed between the lower border ofthe 12th rib and the vertebral column.74911th rib12th ribKidneyCostovertebralangleCostovertebral angleOMARROWMurphy's triad is associated with acute appendicitis.• Pain in the right illiac fossa• Vomiting• Fever

questions.question: 734According to the Tokyo Consensus Guidelines for grading the severity of acute cholecystitis,which of the following conditions is classified under moderate (Grade II) acute cholecystitis?
questions.explanation: If the duration of complaints is >72 hours, the patient is classified as having moderate (GradeII) acute cholecystitis.Acute cholecystitis is treated by keeping the patient nil per oral (NPO), administering intravenousfluids, analgesics, and IV antibiotics.The timing of surgery in acute cholecystitis remains controversial:••If the patient presents within 3 days, emergency cholecystectomy is done.If the patient presents after 3 days, conservative management is done initially. Once theinflammation subsides, cholecystectomy is performed after 6 weeks (interval cholecystectomy).Tokyo Consensus Guidelinesforgrading the severity of acute cholecystitisGrade III (severe) acute cholecystitisAssociated with organ dysfunction750Tokyo Consensus Guidelinesforgrading the severity of acute cholecystitis1. questions.question: A 45-year-old man with a past medical history of diabetes mellitus, hypertension andischemic heart disease presented with fever, nausea and right upper abdominal pain for thepast 2 days. On evaluation, he is hypotensive and has a right upper quadrant palpable mass.Laboratory findings are mentioned below. Which of the following is the most appropriatemanagement for this patient?

options.A: Percutaneous cholecystostomy, followed by interval cholecystectomy
options.C: Conservative management, followed by delayed cholecystectomy after 6 weeks

questions.explanation: The given clinical vignette is suggestive of severe acute cholecystitis (grade III) based on TokyoConsensus Guideline. Patients who have multiple comorbidities and present with severely acutecholecystitis should ideally undergo USG guided percutaneous cholecystostomy, followed by751interval cholecystectomy once the condition has been stabilized..Management of cholecystitis• Nil per oral (NPO)• IV fluids• Analgesics• IV antibiotics• Surgery• Grade III•with comorbidities - a percutaneous cholecystostomy can be performed by a radiologist underultrasound guidance. An interval cholecystectomy once the condition has been stabilized.•• without comorbidities - unless the patient is extremely hemodynamically unstable, operativeintervention (cholecystectomy) should be performed.• Grade I-II• presenting within 3 days - emergency cholecystectomy is done.• presenting after 3 days - conservative management is done initially. Once the inflammationsubsides, cholecystectomy is performed after 6 weeks (interval cholecystectomy).Tokyo Consensus Guidelinesforgrading the severity of acute cholecystitisGrade III (severe) acute cholecystitisAssociated with organ dysfunction1. Respiratory dysfunctionment with dopamine>5 mcg/kg/min, or any dose of noradrenalineDecreased level of consciousnessPaO2/FiO2ratio <300Oliguria; serum creatinine >2mg/dLProthrombin time (PT-INR)>4. Renal dysfunction5. Hepatic dysfunction1.56. Hematological dysfunction3Grade II (moderate) acute cholecystitisPlatelet count, <100,000/mm752Tokyo Consensus Guidelinesforgrading the severity of acute cholecystitisAssociated with dysfunctionof any one of the following: Elevated white blood cell count(>18,000/mm3)Palpable tender mass in the right upper abdominal quadrantDurationof complaints >72 hoursMarked local inflammation (gangrenous cholecystitis, pericholecystic abscess, hepatic abscess, biliary peritonitis, emphysematous cholecystitis)Grade I (mild) acute cholecystitisDoes not meet the criteria ofgrade II or III acute cholecystitis.Acute cholecystitis in a healthy person with no organ dysfunction and mild inflammatory changes in the gall bladder, making cholecystectomya safe and low-risk operativeprocedure.

questions.question: A diabetic patient presents with complaints of right upper quadrant pain, fever and nausea.On examination, there is tenderness over the right upper quadrant. CT scan revealed thefollowing finding. What is the most common organism implicated in this condition?735
questions.explanation: The given clinical scenario and the CT scan showing gas within the wall of the gallbladder arediagnostic of acute emphysematous cholecystitis. Clostridia species are the most commonlyimplicated organisms in acute emphysematous cholecystitis. Other causative organisms include E.coli and anaerobic streptococci.Emphysematous cholecystitis is a rare form of acute cholecystitis where gallbladder wall necrosiscauses gas formation in the lumen or wall.Clinical features include:• Right upper quadrant pain• NauseaVomiting• Fever•Presence of crepitus during physical examinationOn imaging, the condition is diagnosed when there is a radiographic demonstration of air in thegallbladder wall +/- biliary ducts.753Emphysematous cholecystitis has a high mortality rate due to the development of gangrene,perforation, and other complications. Hence, emergency cholecystectomy is indicated for themanagement of these patients. Tube cholecystostomy is done for patients who are not suitable forsurgery.The given image shows a postoperative specimen of an emphysematous gallbladder along with anX-ray showing air in the gallbladder wall.DAILY ROUNDSNote: E. coli is the most commonly implicated organism in acute emphysematous pyelonephritis.

questions.question: A patient in the burns ward complains of right hypochondriac pain and fever. USG reveals athickened, hyperemic gallbladder with sludge formation surrounded by pericholecystic fluidbut no gallstones. Which of the following statements is false regarding this condition?

options.A: CT-guided cholecystostomy is the treatment of choice
options.B: It has a high mortality rate
options.D: E. coli is the causative agent

questions.explanation: The given clinical scenario along with the USG findings point to a diagnosis of acalculouscholecystitis. E. coli is not a causative agent of acalculous cholecystitis.Acute and chronic inflammation of the gallbladder can occur in the absence of stones and arereferred to as acalculous cholecystitis.It is mainly seen in critically ill patients and those recovering from major surgery, trauma, andburns. It has a high mortality rate.The bacterial infections of the gallbladder causing acalculous cholecystitis include:⚫ Leptospira• Streptococcus• Salmonella• Vibrio choleraeClinical features are similar to that of acute calculous cholecystitis, such as:•Right upper quadrant pain• Fever754• Positive Murphy's sign⚫ Leukocytosis••SepsisA USG demonstrates a distended gallbladder with thickened wall, biliary sludge, pericholecysticfluid, and the presence or absence of abscess formation. HIDA scan shows a non-visualization ofthe gallbladder.Acalculous cholecystitis requires urgent intervention. Percutaneous ultrasound or CT-guidedcholecystostomy is the treatment of choice for these patients, as they are usually unfit for surgery.Cholecystectomy is performed after the patient has recovered from the underlying illness.

questions.question: A 25-year-old lady was incidentally found to have gallstones during the abdominalultrasound. She is otherwise healthy and does not complain of any symptoms. In which of thefollowing clinical scenarios you will not advise her for prophylactic cholecystectomy?

options.B: Gallbladder polyp > 1cmSickle cell disease736d) Presence of a 1.5 cm gallstoneQuestion 14:Medical therapy for gallstones using ursodeoxycholic acid will be considered in all of thefollowing conditions, except:a) If the size of the cholesterol stone is < 10mmb) If the patient has biliary pain without any complications
options.D: In the presence of radio-opaque cholesterol gallstones

questions.explanation: Prophylactic cholecystectomy in asymptomatic cholelithiasis is indicated only when gallstones>3 cm.Indications for consideration of prophylactic cholecystectomy in asymptomatic patients:• Risk factors for carcinoma• Choledochal cysts• Gallbladder adenomas• Porcelain (calcified) gallbladder• Solitary gallbladder polyp larger than 1 cm• Choledocholithiasis• Gallstones >3 cm• The patient lives in a remote location from a healthcare facility• Sickle cell disease/spherocytosis•Transplant or immunosuppressant therapy.Note: Some books also mention "Prophylactic cholecystectomy is indicated in asymptomaticcholelithiasis when gallstones >2 cm."

questions.question: A patient with symptomatic gallstones but refusing surgery is at risk of developing all of thefollowing complications except:
questions.explanation: Diverticulosis is not a complication due to gallstones.Clinical complications due to gallstones include the following:•Biliary colic• Acute cholecystitis• Chronic cholecystitis•• Empyema of the gallbladder• Mucocele• Perforation•••Biliary obstruction• Acute cholangitis• Acute pancreatitis• Intestinal obstruction (gallstone ileus).

questions.question: Which of the following statement is false regarding the mucocele of the gallbladder?

options.A: Caused due to prolonged obstruction of cystic duct
options.B: Early cholecystectomy needs to be done
options.C: Obstruction can be seen in the neck of the gallbladder
options.D: A tender, non palpable gallbladder is characteristic of this condition

questions.explanation: The gallbladder is palpable but non-tender in the mucocele of the gallbladder.Mucocele of the gallbladder results from prolonged obstruction of the cystic duct, usually by alarge solitary calculus. The obstructed gall bladder lumen is progressively distended by mucus(mucocele) or by a clear transudate (hydrops) produced by mucosal epithelial cells.It is usually asymptomatic, although chronic right upper quadrant pain may also occur. Onexamination, a visible, easily palpable, non-tender gallbladder, sometimes extending from theright upper quadrant into the right iliac fossa may be seen.Ultrasonography is helpful for the diagnosis.Early cholecystectomy needs to be done, because empyema, perforation, or gangrene maycomplicate the condition.The image below shows mucocele of the gallbladder.756The image below shows empyema of the gallbladder.DAILYROUNDS

questions.question: A middle-aged woman with a history of cholelithiasis was rushed to the casualty withcomplaints of vomiting, abdominal distension, and obstipation. On examination, high-pitchedbowel sounds were heard. Her X-ray erect abdomen is given below. Which statement is falseregarding this condition?737

options.A: It is associated with Rigler's triad
options.B: Jejunum is the most common site of obstruction
options.C: CT scan is the investigation of choice
options.D: Enterotomy is done in the absence of strangulation

questions.explanation: The given clinical scenario with an X-ray showing gas in the biliary tract (pneumobilia) andmultiple air-fluid levels indicating small bowel obstruction is suggestive of gallstone ileus. Thedistal ileum is the most common site to be obstructed in gallstone ileus because it tapers beforeentering the cecum.Gallstone ileus is caused by the obstruction of the intestinal lumen by a gallstone, leading to amechanical blockage. Big gallstones will not be able to pass through the normal cystic duct. Thiscauses inflammation of the gallbladder and results in pressure necrosis. This in turn leads tobiliary-enteric fistula formation.757Plain radiographs demonstrate air-fluid levels consistent with a small bowel obstruction. Rigler'striad is seen in gallstone ileus. It includes:• Intestinal obstruction• Gas in the biliary tract (pneumobilia)•Ectopic gallstone (Radio-opaque shadow in the right iliac fossa)The investigation of choice is the CT scan. Pneumobilia is a ubiquitous finding because the fistulathat permitted a stone to pass into the duodenum allows air into the gallbladder and the biliarytree.•Initial management involves keeping the patient nil per-oral, IV fluids, IV antibiotics, andanalgesics.If there is no strangulation or peritonitis, it can be managed by:Milking the stone beyond ileocaecal junction•Crushing the stone• Enterotomy to remove the stoneIf there is perforation or strangulation, resection and anastomosis are done.Cholecystectomy should be performed to avoid future complications. Fistula closure can beperformed along with cholecystectomy or it can be performed later (two-stage procedure).Given below is a plain X-ray of the erect abdomen showing air in the biliary tract (pneumobilia).A large gallstone causing gallstone ileus is shown below.758

questions.question: In what condition would you see the gallbladder as shown below?
questions.explanation: The given image shows a strawberry gallbladder. Strawberry gallbladder is seen in cholesterolosisand is associated with cholesterol stones.Cholesterolosis is characterized by mucosal villous hyperplasia. The interior of the gallbladderresembles a strawberry. The yellow specks are aggregations of cholesterol crystals and cholesterolesters in the lamina propria. This corresponds to the seeds of a strawberry.Option A: Cholesterol polyposis - Cholecystography or ultrasonography shows negative shadowsin a functioning gallbladder, indicating the presence of a well-defined polyp.Options B and C: Cholecystitis glandularis proliferans/adenomyomatosis - All layers of thegallbladder wall may be thickened, but sometimes, an incomplete septum forms that separate thehyperplastic from the normal layer. Intraparietal "mixed" calculi may be present.

questions.question: A 40-year-old lady presented with colicky abdominal pain, jaundice and generalized pruritus.She has a palpable gallbladder. Which of the following is the least likely cause?

options.A: Stone impacted in the cystic duct
options.B: Stone impacted in the fundus of gallbladder
options.C: Stone impacted within the gallbladder and common bile duct
options.D: Carcinoma of the head of the pancreas

questions.explanation: A stone impacted within the fundus of the gallbladder is least likely to cause jaundice with apalpable gallbladder.According to Courvoisier's law, the presence of a painless, palpable, enlarged gallbladder and mildjaundice, is unlikely due to gallstones. It usually indicates a possibility of carcinoma in the head ofthe pancreas. However, apart from a cancer in the pancreatic head, certain other conditions mayalso cause a palpable gallbladder in presence of jaundice. For example,• Double impacted stones (stones in both the cystic duct and the distal common bile duct)• Primary CBD stone• Oriental cholangiohepatitis759• Mirizzi's syndrome (an impacted gallstone in the cystic duct or neck of the gallbladder due toinflammation, causing common bile duct (CBD) obstruction, jaundice and a palpable gallbladder)These are considered exceptions to Courvoisier's law.

questions.question: A 40-year-old lady presented with abdominal pain, vomiting and jaundice. Her ALP anddirect bilirubin levels were raised. She had undergone laparoscopic cholecystectomy 1 yearback. On USG there is dilatation of biliary radicles. Which of the following is the idealmanagement for this patient?

options.A: Laparoscopic exploration of common bile duct
options.B: Open surgical exploration of common bile duct
options.D: Addition of ursodeoxycholic acid, followed by repeat USG after 10 days

questions.explanation: The given scenario is suggestive of choledocholithiasis. When diagnosed postoperatively (aftercholecystectomy), it should be managed with ERCP + sphincterotomy.Stone detected within 2 years after cholecystectomy is called retained stone. Stone detected morethan 2 years after cholecystectomy is considered recurrent stone.•CBD stone and GB stone detected before cholecystectomy:⚫ ERCP+Sphincterotomy, followed by laparoscopic cholecystectomy after a few days should bedone.CBD stone detected during surgery (intraoperatively):• Laparoscopic cholecystectomy + laparoscopic CBD exploration should ideally be done in thesame sitting to avoid the need for additional operative sitting and anaesthesia.• A transcystic approach is preferred usually.• If there is a small, friable cystic duct; numerous (more than eight) stones in the common bileduct; and large stones (>1 cm), laparoscopic choledocholithotomy is performed.• If laparoscopic choledocholithotomy exploration is not feasible, it would necessitate the need foran open CBD exploration.• A T-tube is placed in the CBD after laparoscopic choledocholithotomy or open CBD exploration.It is followed by a cholangiography to exclude retained stone.•CBD stone detected after surgery:Endoscopic removal (ERCP) with sphincterotomy is usually the management of choice.

questions.question: An 80-year-old woman presented with complaints of fatigue. On imaging, she was found tohave a scleroatrophic gall bladder with impacted stones in it. A large stone was also present inthe common bile duct and the biliary tree is dilated. What is the next step in management?

options.A: Immediately take up patient for cholecystectomy

questions.explanation: An 80-year-old woman with imaging showing a scleroatrophic gall bladder with impacted stonesand a stone in the bile duct is suggestive of chronic cholelithiasis with choledocholithiasis. ERCPis the next line of management for this patient.Choledocholithiasis is the presence of stone in the common bile duct (CBD) or biliary tree. It canbe primary or secondary:••Primary stones are formed in the CBD or biliary tree itself and are rare.Secondary stones are passed from the gallbladder to the CBD. They are easier to manage thanprimary stones.It can be an asymptomatic and incidental finding or present with features such as jaundice (mostcommon), abdominal pain, and fatigue. When there is inflammation of the biliary tree760(cholangitis), the patient will have intermittent pain, fever, and jaundice (Charcot's triad).Investigations:• Liver function tests will show elevated direct bilirubin and alkaline phosphatase levels.• Abdominal ultrasound is the first imaging modality done and may show gallstones and dilatedbile duct (>8 mm).•• CT is sensitive for CBD stones. It shows stones, location, ductal stricture or block, ductaldilatation, and intrahepatic biliary changes.•MRCP is highly sensitive and specific for CBD stones, but it is only diagnostic and interventioncannot be performed.Management:• ERCP with sphincterotomy is the procedure of choice, followed by the removal of stones using adormia basket or placement of a stent.•Despite ERCP being an invasive procedure, it has the advantage of being both a diagnostic andtherapeutic procedure and is more suited for elderly patients who cannot tolerate anesthesia andsurgery.Other options:Option A: Cholecystectomy is not recommended for elderly patients, owing to the risk of old ageand associated anesthetic and surgical complications.Option C: Wait and watch approach can be done for asymptomatic patients, and patients withsmaller stones.Option D: CT is sensitive for CBD stones, but it is only diagnostic and intervention cannot beperformed.

questions.question: 739What is the best investigation in a patient suspected to have an impacted gallstone at theampulla of Vater?
questions.explanation: Endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP) will be the best investigation in themanagement of impacted stone at the ampulla of Vater. It allows the surgeon to visualize thepresence of gallstone at the ampulla of Vater along with the therapeutic extraction of the stone.The following image shows an ERCP procedure (endoscope visible).761RIGHT

questions.question: Which of the following features are part of Reynold's pentad?
questions.explanation: Vomiting and diaphoresis are not part of Reynold's pentad. Reynold's pentad is seen in acutesuppurative cholangitis.

questions.question: A jaundiced patient presented with complaints of colicky abdominal pain and itching all overthe body. USG abdomen showed thickening of the gallbladder wall and pericholecystic fluid.MRCP showed extrinsic compression of the common bile duct, suggestive of Mirizzisyndrome. Identify the incorrect statement about this condition.

options.A: Surgery consists of removing the cystic duct, gallbladder, and the stone
options.B: Cystic duct obstruction will be present
options.C: Fistula forms between the gallbladder and common bile duct

questions.explanation: A palpable gallbladder will not rule out gallstones in Mirizzi syndrome. It is an exception toCourvoisier's law.Courvoisier's law states that in the presence of a painless, palpable, enlarged gallbladder and mildjaundice, the cause is unlikely to be gallstones. Its exceptions include:•• Double impacted stones (stones in both the cystic duct and the distal common bile duct)• Primary CBD stone• Oriental cholangiohepatitis• Mirizzi's syndromeIn Mirizzi's syndrome, gallstones become impacted in the cystic duct or neck of the gallbladderdue to inflammation. This causes common bile duct (CBD) obstruction and jaundice. Thegallbladder is distended and may be palpable.ERCP, PTC (Percutaneous transhepatic cholangiography), or MRCP will usually demonstrate thecharacteristic extrinsic compression of the CBD.Surgery consists of removing the cystic duct, diseased gallbladder, and the impacted stone. Inpatients whose gallbladder is densely adherent to the common bile duct, partial cholecystectomyshould be done.762If left untreated, a fistula forms between the gallbladder and common bile duct(cholecysto-choledochal fistula).

questions.question: Identify the condition.740
questions.explanation: The given image shows a resected specimen of a gallbladder with a polyp on the inner surface.Specimen of gallbladder carcinoma would include an en-bloc dissection of the gall bladder,surrounding liver tissue and regional lymph nodes (option D). In specimens of cholesterolosis,also known as strawberry gallbladder, the gall bladder would appear yellow and coarsely granulardue to the presence lipid nodules (options A and B).Gall bladder polyps are usually incidental findings during abdominal imaging. Most of them arebenign and comprise cholesterol polyps, adenomyomas or inflammatory polyps. Adenomatouspolyps are the most common neoplastic polyps. The majority of patients with polyps are stableand smaller polyps are kept under observation. Cholecystectomy is done for symptomatic patients(biliary colic, pancreatitis), patients >50 years, sessile polyps with thickening >4 mm andpolyps >10 mm.The risk factors for malignancy in an adenomatous polyp include age >50 years, size >10mm, sessile polyp, documented increase in size, and coexistence with gallstones.Other options:Option D: The gallbladder in a patient with carcinoma is removed via an en-bloc dissection withsurrounding liver tissue along with regional lymph nodes. The given image below shows a cutsurface of the resected gallbladder with a tumor at the neck along with liver bed involvement(marked by the red arrow).Options A and B: Cholesterolosis (strawberry gallbladder) is characterized by the accumulation oflipids (triglycerides, cholesterol precursors and cholesterol esters) in the lamina propria of thegallbladder wall. The nodules are less than 1 mm in diameter and there is mucous villoushyperplasia, which gives it a coarse, yellow and granular appearance, giving it a strawberry-like763appearance. The given images below show cholesterolosis.

questions.question: A45-year old lady is found to have a gall bladder polyp of size 1.2cm on abdominal USG. Sheappears to be healthy and is asymptomatic. How will you manage this patient?
questions.explanation: Gallbladder polyps larger than 1 cm have an increased risk of malignancy and should be treated byperforming a cholecystectomy.Management of gallbladder polypGallbladder polypSymptomaticMAsymptomaticSize > 10mmSize 10mmRisk factors such as:Age 50 years- Gallbladder stoneNo risk factorsCholecystectomyRegular follow-upwith ultrasonographyOMARROW

questions.question: What is the treatment of choice for the condition shown below?741
questions.explanation: The X-ray image shows calcification of the gallbladder, also known as porcelain gallbladder. Thiscondition is associated with the risk of gall bladder carcinoma. Cholecystectomy is the treatmentof choice.764Extended cholecystectomy includes removal of the gall bladder with a 2 cm non-anatomical wedgeof the liver and lymphadenectomy. It is performed for stage Ib with perineural, lymphatic,vascular invasion, and stage II of gallbladder carcinoma.

questions.question: All of the following are risk factors for gallbladder carcinoma, except:
questions.explanation: Adenomyomatosis is not a risk factor for carcinoma gallbladder.Adenomyomatosis is a benign condition of the gallbladder characterized by hypertrophy of themucosal epithelium. It invaginates into the thickened muscularis forming Rokitansky-Aschoffsinuses.Risk factors for carcinoma gallbladder:• Gallstones of size >3 cm (most important risk factor)⚫ Porcelain gallbladder•• Anomalous pancreato-biliary junction• Choledochal cyst• Adenomatous polyps• Primary sclerosing cholangitisObesity•Salmonella typhii infection.

questions.question: Which of the following is false regarding gallbladder carcinoma?

options.A: Squamous cell carcinoma is the most common type
options.C: Depth of invasion is the most important prognostic factor

questions.explanation: The most common type of gallbladder carcinoma is adenocarcinoma (80-90%). Squamouscarcinomas also occur and are believed to arise from areas of mucosal squamous metaplasia.Gallbladder carcinoma is a rare malignancy that is seen in the elderly. It is associated with a poorprognosis and is indistinguishable from cholecystitis or cholelithiasis. It is usually diagnosedwhen patients undergo cholecystectomy for gallstones.Its clinical features include right upper quadrant pain, nausea, vomiting, and anorexia. Jaundiceis a late feature. CA 19-9 is elevated in the carcinoma gallbladder and is used for monitoring.The preoperative diagnosis is often made on ultrasonography and followed up by a CT scan orMRI/Magnetic resonance cholangiopancreatography.A percutaneous biopsy under radiological guidance is done for pathological examination. PETscanning helps in detecting metastatic disease.In select cases, a laparoscopic examination is useful in staging the disease. Laparoscopy can alsodetect peritoneal or liver metastases. The most important prognostic factor is the depth ofinvasion (T-stage).765

questions.question: A patient underwent laparoscopic cholecystectomy for cholelithiasis. Histopathology of theresected gall bladder is reported as Stage Tia of gallbladder cancer. What is the next step inmanagement?
questions.explanation: Cholecystectomy is sufficient for gallbladder carcinoma with Tia lesions, wherein the tumorpenetrates the lamina propria but does not invade the muscle layer.Treatment of gallbladder carcinoma (in general):If the carcinoma gall bladder was found incidentally after cholecystectomy:•• Up to stage Ia and stage Ib with negative margins, standard cholecystectomy would sufficeStage Ib with perineural, lymphatic, vascular invasion and stage II, extended cholecystectomyshould be performedIf the initial procedure was performed laparoscopically, the surgeon should examine thelaparoscopic port sites. The finding of disease at the port sites is a sign of generalized peritonealdisease and carries a very poor prognosis. However, resection of port sites is no longerrecommended.Chemotherapy is not required in early gall bladder cancer.
